tsbase

Base class libraries for TypeScript

> npm install tsbase
Get Started

  • Collections

    Intuitive collections with enhanced querying capabilities.

    Use lambda functions to sort, sum, aggregate and otherwise query/manipulate a collection.

    Statefully manage generic lists of things.

    
people = new List<Person>([
  new Person('John Doe', 18),
  new Person('James Doe', 27),
  new Person('Joe Doe', 20),
  new Person('Jack Doe', 45)
]);

people.Sort(p => p.name); // sort list alphabetically

const oldestPerson = people
  .OrderBy([p => p.age]).Last(); // Jack Doe / 45
const youngestPerson = people
  .OrderBy([p => p.age]).First(); // John Doe / 18

const averageAge = people.Average(p => p.age); // 27.5

    HttpClient

    Simple and powerful Async/Await based Http Client.

    Turns a simple GET into the one-two liner you expect it to be.

    
// Simple GET
const client = new HttpClient();
const stringResponse = await client
  .GetStringAsync('https://www.myendpoint.com/api');

// Configure base address or default headers if desired
client.BaseAddress = 'https://www.myendpoint.com/api';
client.DefaultHeaders = [
  {
    key: 'data-type', 
    value: 'application/json'
  }
];

  • Other Generic OOP Goodness

    Libraries for serializing JSON into class instances, handling persistence of data within and beyond a browsing session, and more.

    All classes are designed with extendability in mind, readily taking advantage of generics and dependency injection.

    
// Desired class to instantiate
class Person {
  name: string;
  age: number;
  MakePhoneCall(): void { console.log('ring ring'); }
}
// Raw json data
const peopleDataObj = JSON.parse(rawPeopleData);
// Instantiate a JsonSerializer
const serializer = new JsonSerializer<Person>();

// Trade anonymous objects for class instances
for (const person of peopleDataObj['people']) {
  const personInstance = serializer
    .Serialize(Person, person);
  personInstance.MakePhoneCall();
}
